item.title: Lost Soul Aside: How to Solve the Guiding Pillar Puzzle (Hidden Palace)
item.description:
Throughout Kaser 's extensive journey in Lost Soul Aside , he will clash with a variety of formidable foes, including both humans and the mysterious Voidrax . While the game's fluid combat system often feels straightforward and accessible, players may find themselves challenged by the more intricate puzzles that are essential for story progression.

Upon reaching the Hidden Palace in chapter 2, a significant obstacle presents itself: a vast chamber containing multiple guiding pillars that must be rearranged. This guide outlines the precise steps required to solve this particular puzzle and advance in Lost Soul Aside 's main story.

How to Solve the Guiding Pillar Puzzle in Lost Soul Aside

Upon entering the chamber that holds the Guiding Pillar puzzle, you'll immediately be confronted by a hostile group of Voidrax. These aggressive enemies must be defeated before you can safely begin your attempt at the puzzle. If you are struggling with the combat, consider equipping Seleria's Keepsake from your Trinkets menu. This valuable item not only significantly reduces incoming damage but also boosts your overall damage output, making it an excellent choice for challenging encounters, including difficult boss fights and the game's higher difficulty settings once you unlock them.

The solution to the Guiding Pillar puzzle is to strategically rearrange the pillars by striking them with your Greatsword in a specific sequence. This will cause light to pass through each pillar, ultimately opening the path forward. Begin by positioning yourself directly in front of the sealed door. Locate the first pillar on your right and strike it twice . Then, move to the next pillar to its left and strike it two times as well.

Be careful, as a third strike will move it too far.

The third pillar in the sequence is immovable, so you can ignore it . Proceed to the fourth pillar and strike it only once . Finally, move to the last pillar on the far left and strike it twice . Following these steps will correctly align the pillars, causing them to light up and unlock the door, allowing you to continue your journey through the Hidden Palace.

item.title: NBA 2K26: How to Flashy Pass & Wrap Pass
item.description:
In NBA 2K26 , there are new controls for flashy passing , and there's also a new passing technique to help teams maintain possession. Both of these passes have their uses, so mastering them is great, especially for point guards or playmaking centers, such as Jokic.

Flashy passes, including no-looks, behind-the-back, and over-the-shoulder, are also incredibly popular , given how great they look.

Players can practice these passes and other team moves, such as alley-oops in NBA 2K26 , in quick modes such as Blacktop or scrimmages, the latter of which is available in the Learn 2K menu.

How To Flashy Pass In NBA 2K26

The input for flashy passing has been changed from previous installments of the series, but as long as a player has a high passing stat, they still work just as well.

To perform a flashy pass in NBA 2K26 ​​​, two buttons need to be pressed at the same time .

  • PlayStation: Cross & Circle
  • Xbox: A & B

On either controller, point the Left Stick in the direction you want the pass to go.

Flashy passes can also be performed while going up for a layup or dunk , and will cancel that animation to throw the ball behind.

When the direction of a pass is behind a player or at any other weird angle, flashy passes are often best , as the player will throw the ball over their shoulder, for example. This is much faster than turning around for a normal chest pass .

Trying flashy passes with players who have bad handling and passing is a recipe for more turnovers.

How To Wraparound Pass In NBA 2K26

Wraparound passes or wrap passes are essentially where the passer puts extra effort into passing around a defender , often using their own body to protect the ball . At the cost of a little speed, the pass is less likely to be intercepted. When being pressed or double-teamed , a wrap pass may be necessary .

To perform a wrap pass in NBA 2K26 ​​​, the passer needs to be guarded or under some form of pressure:

  • PlayStation: Double-tap Circle
  • Xbox: Double-tap B

Use the Left Stick to dictate the direction of the pass.

These are the old controls for flashy passing in previous installments of the NBA 2K series.

item.title: How to Get All Exotic Weapons in Destiny Rising
item.description:
Exotic weapons have been the main attraction of Destiny for years, and in Destiny: Rising, players will have a chance to obtain some of the most iconic Exotics from the franchise. Tools of destruction, such as the Crimson Hand-Cannon, or the memorable Borealis from Destiny 2, and also, some new weapons are available for grabs, if players know where to look.

This guide will explain everything about the Exotic weapon system, including Battle Pass, Catalysts, differences with Mythic Weapons, and how to get all the exotic weapons currently available in the game.

How do Exotic Engrams work in Destiny: Rising?

Exotic Engrams work a bit differently in Destiny: Rising , and veteran Guardians (New Lights, too) should know that it's not so simple to get these precious items. For starters, some Engrams allow players to choose the rewards they want, but it's not the case with all of them.

Exotic Engrams are rewarded by completing the end-game activities in Destiny: Rising , which are available once players complete most of the Main Story missions and reach a Team Level of at least 50. Once players have completed Chapter 4-2 and the Armageddon mission, they will unlock Gauntlet Ops and Legendary Campaign modes, which allow them to get Exotic Engrams as rewards.

The 14-Day Sign In event also grants 2 Engrams (one at Stage 7 , and another at Stage 14 ) which will allow players to choose from three different Exotic Weapons: Huckleberry , Borealis , and Crimson .

In particular cases, such as the Seasonal Featured Exotics, these need to be collected through the Battle Pass. Those who purchase the Premium Battle Pass will have access to these weapons earlier, while the Free - to - play players will only obtain them by completing all the levels of the battle pass (unlocked at level 50). Furies III and its Catalyst are available this season, and to obtain the Catalyst, players need to purchase it using Battle Pass Tokens (also granted by completing the Battle Pass Levels).

Differences Between Exotic and Mythic Weapons

Until Destiny 2 , Exotic Weapons were the pinnacle of armament for Guardians all across the Sol System; however, in Destiny: Rising , there's a new weapon category called Mythic Weapons .

Mythic weapons are special since they are one level above Legendary weapons, and can roll with Mythic grade Perks which are significantly better than the Rare and Legendary Perks. Mythic Weapons are obtained in the following sources :

  • Season Pass Engram Rewards
  • The Gauntlet Pinnacle Rewards
  • Event Rewards
  • Legendary Story Mission Rewards

item.title: Last Epoch: Rogue Marksman Build (Season 3)
item.description:
Bow builds for Rogues in Last Epoch can be just as strong as everything if players get the right synergies going, and with the Marksman subclass, you'll get a ton of additional options for making your ranged attacks stronger.

This guide is a Rogue Marksman build for Last Epoch that combines a crit-based build with a burst-heavy, DoT based one that works surprisingly well when everything is put together. It's great for clearing endgame maps, and it's not too shabby in terms of early-game progression either.

Best Puncture Rogue Build in Last Epoch

For this build, we'll be using Puncture to deal great single-target and AoE damage , but this skill alone won't be the only source of DPS. The build will also make heavy use of DoT effects, especially Bleed and Poison. By going down the Puncture DoT route, you'll be able to skirt around the low AoE and DPS output of early-game Bow Rogue in Last Epoch without having to rely on other active skills.

Early Game Rogue Puncture Build

Puncture makes you fire an arrow that penetrates every enemy in a straight line. This costs no mana, but the damage output is fairly low by itself . To supplement its DPS, take the passive nodes in its skill tree that give Puncture a chance to inflict Bleed on-hit .

Acid Flask complements Puncture's bleed damage by adding Poison to the list of DoT effects you inflict on enemies . This stacks on top of Bleed procs, letting you deal large amounts of damage over time without having to attack enemies. Like all other DoT builds, this allows you to kite enemies more efficiently, accelerating your early game progress.

Shift and Decoy are your main defensive abilities . The former lets you dodge and reposition, while the other draws enemy aggro away from you. Decoy is especially helpful with this build since you won't have many other defensive stats and abilities.

To play this build, just spam Puncture while moving towards your next destination and let the DoTs do their job. Throw Acid Flask at dense packs, elites, and bosses to reduce their resistances and add even more Dot damage.

Use whatever skill you prefer for the last vacant slot. This will be replaced with Detonating Arrow later.

Puncture Mutilate Rogue Marksman Build in Last Epoch

The build remains more or less the same once you unlock the Marksman subclass, though it will become significantly stronger, and you'll get access to some strong synergies as you level up your Specialized skills.

Detonating Arrow Build

Once you unlock the Marksman subclass, you'll get access to Detonating Arrow, which we will use primarily to stack more Poison on enemies. Take Scorpion Arrow and Deadly Ailments, then slowly work your way toward Rapid Detonation at the bottom-left of the skill tree as you level this skill up.

Depending on your Poison chance, Detonating Arrow can inflict up to large amounts of Poison stacks per cast to every enemy it hits in its area of effect. This is great for general mob clearing, but it only gets better once you add Puncture to the mix.

Puncture Build

The reason we're speccing Detonating Arrow for Poison is because of the interaction between the Scalebane and Mutilate passives from the Puncture skill tree. Scalebane converts all Bleed-related effects on Puncture to Poison-based ones — your Chance to Inflict Bleed becomes Chance to Inflict Poison, and Chance to Shred Armor becomes Chance to Reduce Poison Resistance. More importantly, even though it's not explicitly stated, Scalebane also affects Mutilate .

Mutilate makes every third arrow from Puncture consume Bleed stacks to deal all the remaining damage that those stacks have left in one big burst. With Scalebane, Mutilate will instead affect Poison stacks. With Acid Flask and Detonating Arrow, this Last Epoch Rogue Bow build becomes capable of detonating any Poison DoTs on an enemy with Puncture.

Specialize Puncture first, and try not to stray too far from the build above. You can respec in Last Epoch , but if you reset your skill passives, you'll have to level that skill again.

Acid Flask Build

For Acid Flask, prioritize getting Poison Pools and Amatoxic Pools . This turns Acid Flask into a lingering area ability that continuously Poisons enemies while applying Efficacious Toxin, which increases the DoT damage enemies take.

After these, work your way to Toxic Salvo and Barrage so you can throw more flasks per skill cast, greatly increasing the ability's area of effect.

Shift Build

Shift is mostly here for mobility, so take skills that decrease its cooldown and add other bonuses. Spend your first set of points on Velocity, Momentum, and Swift Recovery before proceeding down the Shadowslip branch, ultimately getting Arrival Gift for the Acid Flask synergy.

Decoy Build

Frostfire Powder and its associated nodes are great for turning Decoy into an even stronger crowd control tool. Pair this with Backup Buddy to get an extra Decoy charge, and once you get enough points, grab Grand Diversion too for even more decoys. Alternatively, take Acid Fumes for more Poison.

This skill is primarily used against elite packs and bosses. For general fighting, you'll want to rely on your other skills more. If you think you don't need Decoy as much, you can replace this with Dark Quiver with Lacerating Arrows or Smoke Bomb with Toxic Cloud.

Gear and Preferred Stats

For this build, you'll want to get items that give you an added chance to inflict DoT effects like Poison, Ignite, and Bleed . If you're ailment chance goes beyond 100%, you'll then have a chance to inflict an additional ailment stack on-hit. Preferably, you should have as much Chance to Inflict Poison as possible to make Puncture/Mutilate stronger later on.

As for the rest of your items and gear stats, focus on getting the following

  • Bow Damage
  • Damage Over Time
  • Poison Damage
  • Dexterity
  • Defensive stats (evasion, elemental resistances, armor, and health)
  • Mana

Monoliths in Last Epoch are great for target-farming equipment.

If you're looking for Unique weapons that can work well with this build, try the following:

  • Shadowstring grants crit chance, bonus charges for Shift and Smoke Bomb, as well as Ward when you use the latter two skills.
  • Hydra Arc gives Poison stats, levels to Dexterity skills, and bonus elemental damage. When you Evade, you cast your most recently used bow attack at a nearby enemy (excluding channeled attacks and ones that have cooldowns).
  • Longshot grants bonus elemental and physical damage as well as Life Leech as Health on Bow Damage. Puncture cannot be evaded and it deals more damage against distant enemies.

Passive Skills

Since the build won't be using elemental damage, take the nodes in the bottom-half of the Marksman tree. The Prolonged Demise node is especially good considering the DoT focus of the build, and later on, grab Barbed Arrows and Poison Tipped Arrows at the top side of the tree.

As for everywhere else, it all depends on preference. If you're dying too much, consider getting skills that increase health and evasion. If you're running out of mana often, get the Sapping Strikes node from the Rogue tree . If it's damage you want, attack speed is great for stacking Poison and reaching the third Puncture hit that detonates Poison.

Notable Marksman passives include:

  • Draining Arrows: Increases bow attack speed and restores health when you hit enemies.
  • Assassin's Quiver: Increases bow damage and crit chance.
  • Prolonged Demise: Reduces the effect of DoTs on you while increasing the power of your own DoT effects when using a bow.
  • Barbed Arrows: Gain bonus physical damage, Phys Res Shred Chance, and Chance to Inflict Bleed on Bow Hits.
  • Poison Tipped Arrows: Gain Poison Penetration, Bow Poison Chance, and Poison Duration.
  • Barrage of Pain: Gain Barrage of Pain stacks on bow hits, with each stack increasing your crit chance.
  • Perfect Aim: Barrage of Pain stacks now also increase your crit strike multiplier and restores health on crits.

For the regular Rogue tree, we recommend getting it to at least 22 points, with two points two Sapping Strikes to help with health and mana regeneration.
